lesson.name: Lesson 2.10: Graphing Linear Inequalities in Two Variables, Part 1

page.title: 2.10.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will write, solve, and graph linear inequalities in two variables.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Determine which side of the line the solutions to the inequality will fall, given a two-variable inequality and the graph of the related equation.
  • Describe the graph that represents the solutions to a linear inequality in two variables.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 2.10.1: Using Computation and Reasoning
  • 2.10.2: Finding Solutions to Inequalities on the Coordinate Plane
  • 2.10.2: Self Check
  • 2.10.3: Sketching Solutions to Inequalities
  • 2.10.3: Self Check
  • 2.10.4: Shading Boundary Line Regions

After that, you‚Äôll practice and review.

  • 2.10.5: Practice
  • 2.10.6: Summary

page.title: 2.10.1: Using Computation and Reasoning
page.contents:
Here is an expression: 2ùë•+3ùë¶

Decide if the values in each ordered pair,(ùë•,ùë¶), make the value of the expression less than, greater than, or equal to 12.

  1. (0, 5)
  2. (6, 0)
  3. (-1, -1)
  4. (-5, 10)

Enter your answers here:

Compare your answers:

  1. greater than 12
  2. equal to 12
  3. less than 12
  4. greater than 12

page.title: 2.10.2: Finding Solutions to Inequalities on the Coordinate Plane
page.contents:
Activity

Here are four inequalities. Study each inequality assigned to your group and work with your group to:

  • Find some coordinate pairs that represent solutions to the inequality and some coordinate pairs that do not represent solutions.
  • Plot both sets of points. Either use two different colors or two different symbols like X and O.
  • Plot enough points until you start to see the region that contains solutions and the region that contains non-solutions. Look for a pattern describing the region where solutions are plotted.

\(x\;\geq\;y\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Your answer may vary, but a sample graph (blue points are solutions and yellow points are not solutions) includes the following:

\(x\;\geq\;y\)



\(-2y\;\geq\;-4\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Your answer may vary, but a sample graph (blue points are solutions and yellow points are not solutions) includes the following: 

\(-2y\;\geq\;-4\)



\(3x < 0\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Your answer may vary, but a sample graph (blue points are solutions and yellow points are not solutions) includes the following:
\(3x < 0\)



\(x + y > 10\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Your answer may vary, but a sample graph (blue points are solutions and yellow points are not solutions) includes the following: 

\(x + y > 10\)


 


Video: Finding Solutions to Inequalities on the Coordinate Plane

Watch the following video to learn more about solutions to inequalities on the coordinate plane.

That's correct! Check yourself: The ordered pair (‚Äì4, 0) is in the shaded region.
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Plot the ordered pair. Is it in the shaded region? The answer is (‚Äì4, 0).

page.title: 2.10.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Verify Solutions to an Inequality in Two Variables

Previously we learned to solve inequalities with only one variable. We will now learn about inequalities containing two variables. In particular, we will look at linear inequalities in two variables which are very similar to linear equations in two variables.

Linear inequalities in two variables have many applications. If you ran a business, for example, you would want your revenue to be greater than your costs‚Äîso that your business made a profit.

Linear Inequality

A linear inequality is an inequality that can be written in one of the following forms:

\(Ax+By>C\)          \(Ax+By\geq C\)          \(Ax+By<C          \(Ax+By\leq C\)

Where A and B are not both zero.


Recall that an inequality with one variable had many solutions. For example, the solution to the inequality x > 3 is any number greater than 3. We showed this on the number line by shading in the number line to the right of 3, and putting an open parenthesis at 3. See the figure below.


Similarly, linear inequalities in two variables have many solutions. Any ordered pair (x, y) that makes an inequality true when we substitute in the values is a solution to a linear inequality.


Solution to a Linear Inequality

An ordered pair (\(x, y)\) is a solution to a linear inequality if the inequality is true when we substitute the values of x and y.


Example: Determine whether each ordered pair is a solution to the inequality y > x + 4 :

  1. \((0, 0)\)
  2. \((1, 6)\)
  3. \((2, 6)\)
  4. \((‚àí5, ‚àí15)\)
  5. \((‚àí8, 12)\)

Solution
A.

\((0, 0)\)

 \(y>x+4\)

Substitute 0 for x and 0 for y.

 \(0\;\overset?>0+4\)

Simplify.

\(0\not>4\)

So, \((0,0)\) is not a solution to \(y>x+4.\)


B.

\((1,6)\)

\(y>x+4\)

Substitute 1 for x and 6 for y

 \(6\;\overset?>1+4\)

Simplify.

\(6>5\)

So, \((1,6)\) is a solution to \(y>x+4.\)


C.

\((2,6)\)

 \(y>x+4\)

 Substitute 2 for x and 6 for y

\(6\;\overset?>2+4\)

Simplify.

\(6\not>6\)

So, \((2,6)\) is not a solution to \(y>x+4\).


D.

\((‚àí5,‚àí15)\)

\(y>x+4\)

 Substitute -5 for x and -15 for y

\( -15\overset?{>-5+4}\)

Simplify.

\( -15\not>-1\)

So, \((‚àí5,‚àí15)\) is not a solution to \(y>x+4\).


E.

\((‚àí8,12)\)

\(y>x+4\)

 Substitute -8 for x and 12 for y

\( 12\;\overset?{>-8}+4\)

Simplify.

\(12>-4\)

So, \((‚àí8,12)\) is a solution to \(y>x+4.\)

 

Try It: Verify Solutions to an Inequality in Two Variables

Determine whether each ordered pair is a solution to the inequality y > x ‚àí 3 :

  1. (0, 0)
  2. (4, 9)
  3. (‚àí2, 1)
  4. (‚àí5, ‚àí3)
  5. (5, 1)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

  1. yes; Substitute 0 for x and 0 for y.

      •  \(y > x ‚àí 3\)
      • \(0\;\overset?>\;0\;-\;3\)
      • \(0 > ‚àí3\)

  1. yes; Substitute 4 for x and 9 for y.

      •  \(y > x ‚àí 3\)
      • \(9\;\overset?>\;4\;-\;3\)
      • \(9 > 1\)

  1. yes; Substitute ‚àí2 for x and 1 for y.

      •  \(y > x ‚àí 3\)
      • \(1\;\overset?>\;-2\;-\;3\)
      • \(1 > ‚àí5\)

  1. yes; Substitute ‚àí5 for x and ‚àí3 for y.

      •  \(y > x ‚àí 3\)
      • \(-3\;\overset?>\;-5\;-\;3\)
      • \(‚àí3 > ‚àí8\)

  1. no; Substitute 5 for x and 1 for y.

      •  \(y > x ‚àí 3\)
      • \(1\;\overset?>\;5\;-\;3\)
      • \(1\;\not>\;2\)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won‚Äôt get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I‚Äôd like to retry the self check.
I'm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.10.3: Sketching Solutions to Inequalities
page.contents:
Activity

1. Here is a graph that represents solutions to the equation  x‚àíy=5 x ‚àí y = 5 .

Sketch 4 quick graphs representing the solutions to each of these inequalities:

x‚àíy<5 x ‚àí y < 5


x‚àíy‚â§5 x ‚àí y ‚â§ 5


x‚àíy>5 x ‚àí y > 5


x‚àíy‚â•5 x ‚àí y ‚â• 5



Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

\( x-y<5 \)

\( x-y \leq5 \)

\( x-y>5 \)

\( x-y \geq5 \)



2. For each graph, write an inequality whose solutions are represented by the shaded part of the graph.


A

B

C

D

Enter your answers here:

Compare your answers:

  1. \( x>3 \)
  2. \( y \leq -2 \)
  3. \( y>x \)
  4. \( y ‚â§ x or x ‚â• y \)




Extend Your Thinking


  1. The points (7,3) and (7,5) are bot in the solution region of the inequality x-2y<3.
    1. Compute x-2y for both of these points.
    2. Which point comes closest to satisfying the equation x-2y=3?  That is, for which (x,y) pair is x-2y closest to 3?
  2. The points (3,2) and (5,2) are also in the solution region. Which of these points comes closest to satisfying the equation x-2y=3?
  3. Find the point in the solution region that comes even closer to satisfying the equation x-2y=3.  What is the valuer of x-2y?
  4. For the points (5,2) and (7,3), x-2y=1.  Find another point in the solution region for which x-2y=1.
  5. Find x-2y for the point (5,3). Then find two points that give the same answer.

Enter your answers here:

  1. Answers:
    1. 1 and -3
    2. \((7,3)\)
  2.  -1 and 1. (5,2)
  3. Sample response: \(6‚àí2‚ãÖ2=2\)
  4. Sample response: \((3,1)\). Any point on the line \(y=\frac12x-\frac12\)  will work.
  5. Answers:
    1. -1
    2. Sample points: \((3,2)\) (from previous work), \((1,1)\). Any point on the line \(y=\frac12x+\frac12\)  will work.

page.title: 2.10.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Determine which side of the line the solutions to the inequality will fall, given a two-variable inequality and the graph of the related equation.
  • Describe the graph that represents the solutions to a linear inequality in two variables.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 2.10.1: Using Computation and Reasoning
    • In this activity, you were familiarized with the computation and reasoning that you will need later to determine the solution region of a linear inequality in two variables.
  • 2.10.2: Finding Solutions to Inequalities on the Coordinate Plane
    • In this activity, you built on your understanding that a linear inequality in one variable has many solutions, which are represented by all the points on one side of a number on a number line. You also recalled that a linear equation in two variables has many solutions, which are represented by all the points on the graph of the equation.
  • 2.10.2: Self Check
  • 2.10.3: Sketching Solutions to Inequalities
    • In this activity, you looked at the regions that represent solutions and non-solutions to inequalities. You recognized that the boundary between the two regions is the graph of an equation that is related to the inequality.
  • 2.10.3: Self Check
  • 2.10.4: Shading Boundary Line Regions
    • In this activity, you considered how to make decisions about which side of the boundary line to shade.

After these activities, you completed the following practice.

  • 2.10.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you‚Äôve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

page.title: 2.10.4: Shading Boundary Line Regions
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

1. The line in each graph represents \( y=2x \). Which graph represents \(2x>y\)?

A

B

C

D


2. Explain your reasons for choosing that graph.

    Enter your answers here:

    Compare your answers:

    1. Graph C
    2. Sample response: I substituted the coordinates of a few points above the line into the inequality and found that they are all not solutions. The point (0,0), which is on the line, is also not a solution. I concluded that the points on and above the line are not solutions, and the region below the line represents the solutions.

page.title: 2.10.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Recognize the Relation Between the Solutions of an Inequality and its Graph

Now, we will look at how the solutions of an inequality relate to its graph. Let‚Äôs think about the number line shown previously again. The point x = 3 separated that number line into two parts. On one side of 3 are all the numbers less than 3. On the other side of 3 all the numbers are greater than 3. See the figure below.


The solution of \( x>3 \) is the shaded part of the number line to the right of \( x = 3 \)

Similarly, the line y = x +4 separates the plane into two regions. On one side of the line are points with y < x 4. On the other side of the line are the points with y > X + 4. We call the line \( y > X + 4 \) a boundary line. 

Boundary Line
The line with equation \( Ax + By = C \) is the boundary line that separates the region where \( Ax + By > C \) from the region where \( Ax + By < C \). 


For an inequality in one variable, the endpoint is shown with a parenthesis or a bracket depending on whether or not \( a \) is included in the solution: 


Similarly. for an inequality in two variables. the boundary line is shown with a solid or dashed line to show whether or not it the line is included in the solution. 

\( Ax + By < C \) \( Ax + By \leq C \)
\( Ax + By > C \) \( Ax + By \geq C \)
Boundary line is \( Ax + By = C \) Boundary line is \( Ax + By = C \)
Boundary line is not included in solution.  Boundary line is included in solution.
Boundary line is dashed.  Boundary line is solid. 


Now, let‚Äôs take a look at what we found in the example above. We‚Äôll start by graphing the line \( y = x + 4 \), and then we‚Äôll plot the five points we tested, as shown in the graph. See the figure below.


In the previous example, we found that some of the points were solutions to the inequality \( y > x + 4 \) and some were not.

Which of the points we plotted are solutions to the inequality \( y > x + 4 \)? 

The points \( (1, 6) \) and \( (-8, 12) \) are solutions to the inequality \( y > x + 4 \). Notice that they are both on the same side of the boundary line \( y > x + 4 \). 

The two points \( (0, 0) \) and \( (-5, -15) \) are on the other side of the boundary line \( y = x + 4 \), and they are not solutions to the inequality \( y > x + 4 \). For those two points. \( y < x + 4 \). 

What about the point \( (2, 6) \)? Because \( 6 = 2 + 4 \), the point is a solution to the equation \( y = x + 4 \), but not a solution to the inequality \( y > x + 4 \) so the point \( (2, 6) \) is on the boundary line. 

Let's take another point above the boundary line and test whether or not it is a solution to the inequality \( y > x + 4 \). The point \( (0, 10) \) clearly looks to above the boundary line, doesn't it? Is it a solution to the inequality? 

\( y > x + 4 \)
\( 10 > 0 + 4 \)
\( 10 > 4 \)

So, \( (0, 10) \) is a solution to \( y > x + 4 \). 

Any point you choose above the boundary line is a solution to the inequality \( y > x + 4 \). All points above the boundary line are solutions. 

Similarly, all points below the boundary line, the side with \( (0, 0) \) and \( (‚àí5, ‚àí15) \), are not solutions to \( y > x + 4 \), as shown in the figure below.


The graph of the inequality \( y > X + 4 \) is shown in below. 

The line \( y = X + 4 \) divides the plane into two regions. The shaded side shows the solutions to the inequality \( y > X + 4 \). 

The points on the boundary line, those where\( y = x + 4 \), are not solutions to the inequality \( y > x + 4 \), so the line itself is not part of the solution. We show that by making the line dashed, not solid. 


Try It: Recognize the Relation Between the Solutions of an Inequality and its Graph

The graph of \(y=\frac12x-3\) is shown here.


Sketch the graph of \(y<\frac12x-3\) using Desmos or a graphing calculator. Then select the Solution button to check your work.


Here is how to sketch the graph of the inequality:

\(y<\frac12x-3\)


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won‚Äôt get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I‚Äôd like to retry the self-check.
I'm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.10.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which graph represents the inequality y ‚â§ 3x + 2?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: In the shaded region, values of y are greater than values of \(3x + 2.\)
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: In the shaded region, values of y are greater than values of 3x+2.
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: The values along the boundary line are solutions to the inequality.
Correct! Check yourself: The shaded region is below the solid line.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 2.10.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1-5, determine whether each ordered pair is a solution to the inequality \(y > x ‚àí 1\).

1. \(0,1)\)

Correct! Yes

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.10.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
